Fig. 1 Comparison of adsorption energies of one boron atom, two boron atoms and carbon atom on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces. The calculations are performed on slabs around 10 Å x 10 Å. The corresponding configures is presented in Figs. S1 and S2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 The Wulff construction of χ-Fe5C2 crystallite with different boron atom coverage: a) boron free, b) 1/40 ML, c) 1/20 ML, d) 1/10 ML and e) 1/6 ML. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The optimized configurations of C, H, O, CO adsorption on clean (510) surface（a to d）and (510) surface with B atom at 4 F iron site (e to h), value below the figures is the corresponding adsorption energy. Red and white balls represent oxygen and hydrogen atoms, carbon atoms in lattice and CO are represented by grey balls, while adsorb carbon atom is represented by a yellow one. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 a) deformation charge density between (510) surface with B adsorbed at the Fe 4-fold hollow site and a boron atom and clean (510) surface, the area with increased and reduced electron density are marked by yellow and blue respectively b）-pCOHP between carbon atom adsorbed at site 1 and coordinated iron atoms on (510) surface (red Bfree line) and (510) surface with boron atom adsorbed at 4-fold hollow site (bule Bms line). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Energy diagram of CO direct dissociation on (010)0.25, ( 11 1 ̅ ). (510), (021), ( 31 2 ̅ ) and (311) p(1 ×1) supercells. The energies of most stable adsorption configurations, initial states, transition states and final states of CO activation are presented. The total energies of the CO molecule in the gas phase and the clean slab are set to 0. More detailed structural and energetic information of configurations involved is presented in Fig. S7 and Table S7. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Migration of adsorbed boron atoms from the most stable sites on a) (510), b) (021), c) (311) and d) (010)0.25. The configurations involved were also included. The energies of most stable configurations of boron adsorption and boron hydrogen co-adsorption are taken as 0 eV. Developing advanced Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) technology to acquire fuel and valuable chemicals from non-petroleum sources more efficiently is one of the important tasks in heterogeneous catalysis and chemical engineering research. With the purpose of improving iron-based FTS catalyst, we explored the modification effect of boron on the χ-Fe5C2 catalyst by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Boron atom adsorption on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces is considered to modulate the stability as well as the activity of CO activation on FTS process. Anti-coking can be observed when boron atom adsorbs on χ-Fe5C2 catalyst due to the competitive adsorption and repulsive interactions between carbon and boron atoms. More open and active planes, such as (311), (021), and (31 2 ̅ ) facets, can expose in the morphology of χ-Fe5C2 when boron atom adsorbs on χ-Fe5C2. It is found that co-adsorbed boron atoms have little effect on the barrier of CO direct dissociation in most cases, while there is also particular situation that CO is adsorbed and activated on boron with carbon termination. Our work shed light on the promoting effects of boron adsorption on CO activation, which can provide useful guide for the design of novel iron-based FTS catalysts. Graphical Abstract ga1 Boron atoms adsorption increases the ratio of (311), (021) and (31 2 ̅ ) surfaces which are of lower CO activation barrier exposed. Keywords Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Hägg carbide Boron promoter Morphology CO activation 1 Introduction Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) has been widely applied in the conversion of coal and methane into liquid fuels via synthesis gas platform in recent decades [1,2]. FTS is also expected to play a pivotal role in the utilization of green carbon sources in the near future and keeps attracting interest for a long while [3–5]. The iron-based FTS catalyst, known for its low cost and high selectivity toward olefin and broad operating temperature window, has been already successfully used in industry at the scale of million tons [6,7]. On the other hand, there are some drawbacks of the iron-based catalyst in activity and stability compared to cobalt- and ruthenium-based catalysts [8–10]. There is still great demand in preparing advanced catalysts with higher activity, stability and better ability to produce high-value products via the FTS procedure. Adding promoters is one of the most practical and effective methods in iron-based catalyst development. The active phase, which is χ-Fe5C2 in most cases [11,12], has been modulated by promoters such as copper, potassium, silica in many aspects including crystallite morphology, binding strength of important reaction intermediates and the barrier of elementary reaction steps [13–18]. Finding novel promoters besides alkali/alkali-earth metals and noble metals and understanding the mechanism of promotion effect are of great importance. Among the candidates, boron and its oxides are particularly promising for their unique electronic properties. There have been increasingly more evidence indicating that boron can optimize the activity, selectivity and stability of many kinds of catalysts. It has been reported that boron can increase the activity of Pd catalyst in methanol synthesis from CO and H2 as boron in sub-surface layer inducing the downshift of d-band center of Pd from Fermi-level [19]. On the selectivity of cobalt-based FTS catalyst, Li et al. reported that a small amount of H3BO3 additive increased the chain growth factor, reduced methane production and increased the olefin/paraffin ratio [20]. The positive effect of boron on catalyst stability has been observed in Co [21–23], Ni [24–26], Cu [27] and Pt [28]. The formation of coke on the cobalt FTS catalyst and nickel methanation catalyst is suppressed by introducing boron, which was evidenced by XPS and temperature-programmed hydrogenation [23]. The mechanism of anti-coking effect has been revealed by Saeys et al. with DFT calculations [23–25]. There is a competition in adsorption between boron and carbon atoms on the surface and the presence of surface and subsurface boron atoms destabilizes adsorbed carbon atoms. For the case of copper-based catalyst, B2O3 acts as a structural promoter to increase the dispersion and retards the growth of copper nanoparticles[27]. Dadras et al. studied the effect of boron doping in Pt nanoclusters supported on MgO with DFT, and found that the interaction between boron and platinum prevents Pt atom from migration and destabilizes carbon adsorbed on the cluster. This work suggested that the boron promoter has both anti-coking and sintering-preventing effect [28]. There are also attempts to modulate the iron-based FTS catalyst with boron. In 1980s′, amorphous iron boron alloy was used as the catalyst precursor for FTS [29–31]. A recent study carried out by Gosh et al. found that when using boron-promoted iron FTS catalyst prepared by the hydrothermal method, more than 50% of hydrocarbon products were C2-C4 alkenes [32]. Wan et al. evaluated the effect of boron oxide on iron-based FTS catalyst. They concluded that the doping of boron oxide increases the dispersion of iron oxide and prevents it from being reduced. Better anti-coking abilities of boron oxide promoted catalyst was attributed to the electron transferring from iron to boron oxide, which weakens the adsorption of CO and enhances the surface H/C ratio [33]. To prepare iron-based FTS catalyst with better utilization of boron promoters, a comprehensive understanding of the boron promoting effect is in need. According to previous works, boron and boron oxide co-exist and play different roles in iron-based FTS catalyst. Morphology, electronic structure of active phase and the binding strength of key intermediates will be affected by boron/boron oxide modification. Investigation on the interaction between different types of boron species and the active phase experimentally is a difficult job due to the limitation of characterization methods, whereas theoretical calculation with density functional theory (DFT) provides an opportunity to look into the physical chemistry of the promotion effect. Boron oxide may act as support and structural promoters like silica or electronic promoter to affect the hydrogen adsorption, while the interaction between boron oxide and iron carbide is quite complicated. As the first step of systematical studies, here we focused on the interaction between boron atom and the surfaces of active phase χ-Fe5C2 in this work, and would deal with boron oxide and other boron species in the future. Adsorption of boron on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces was first investigated to evaluate the interaction between promoter and catalyst. Then the bonding of C, H, O and CO to the surface was assessed considering the co-adsorption of boron, with particular attention paid to coke-resistance. Next, we took CO activation as a probe reaction to investigate the effect of boron modification on catalyst activity. The crystallite morphology of χ-Fe5C2 was analyzed by the Wulff construction to compare the proportion of active surfaces exposed under the affection of boron adsorption. In addition, the CO dissociation barriers were calculated on boron adsorbed surface. With all these results together, it was expected to obtain more insights into the modulation effect of boron atom on the stability and activity of χ-Fe5C2 catalyst. 2 Methods and models Spin polarized periodic density functional theory calculation was carried out with Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP)[34,35]. The valence-core interaction is described with the projector augmented wave (PAW) [36,37] approach. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to treat the exchange-correlation energy [38]. Plane waves with a cutoff energy of 400 eV was adopted. The k points sampling in the Brillouin zone was performed using the Γ-centered Monkhorst-Pack scheme [39]. Electron smearing near the Fermi level was dealt with the first order Methfessel-Paxton method with a width of 0.2 eV [40]. 10−4 eV and 0.03 eV/Å were adopted as the convergence criteria for electronic self-consistent iteration and geometric optimization, respectively. Climbing image nudged elastic band (CI-NEB) method with a convergence criterion of 0.05 eV/ Å was used to find the transition states of CO dissociation [41,42], which were confirmed by vibrational frequency calculations. VASPKIT was employed for input file preparation of VASP calculations and the d-band center analysis [43]. Bader charge analysis were carried out with the code from Henkelman group [44–46], while the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) analysiswere implemented with LOBSTER [47–50]. The monoclinic bulk χ-Fe5C2 structure in C2/c symmetry was used to build the surface models. The optimized lattice constants of bulk χ-Fe5C2 are a = 11.537 Å, b = 4.502 Å, c = 4.984 Å with β = 97.62°, which are consistent with experimental values [51]. 15 facets including (001), (010)0.25, (011), (101), (10 1 ̅ ), (110), (111), (111)0.61, (11 1 ̅ ), (510), (021), (311), (31 2 ̅ ), (31 1 ̅ ), and (312) surfaces are modeled by periodic slabs of area around 10 Å x 10 Å. 15 Å vacuum layers were added between the slabs to avoid the artificial interaction perpendicular to the slabs. All the slabs were cleaved at the origin of unit cell, except for models of (010)0.25 and (111)0.61, which were cleaved at a fraction distance from the origin indicated by the subscript of the crystal indices. To calculate the surface energy, thick slabs in which all the atoms were allowed to relax were adopted. In the calculation of adsorption energy and CO dissociation barrier, thinner slabs in which layers of atoms from bottom fixed were used. More detailed information about k-points sampling, composition of slabs and atoms fixed/relaxed are presented in Supporting information Table S1 and S2. The thickness of three surfaces (510), (021) and (31 1 ̅ ) has been tested to ensure that models are proper for surface energy study while the results are presented in Table S3. Adsorption energy of boron or carbon atom E ads is defined as Eq. 1, where E ads-slab, E slab, and E ref represent the energy of boron/carbon atom on slab, the energy of clean slab and the energy of a boron/carbon atom in the bulk phase. Graphite and orthorhombic γboron containing 28 atoms in a unit cell are adopted as bulk carbon and boron in this study. (1) E ads = E ads − slab − E slab − E ref In this work, only stoichiometric and symmetric surfaces are considered in calculation of surface energies. Surface energy γ 0 is calculated as Eq.2, where Ebulk refers to the energy of a conventional unit cell of χ-Fe5C2 containing 20 Fe atoms and 8 C atoms, n is the ratio of atom numbers of slab to the unit cell and A is the area of the surface unit cell. (2) γ 0 = E slab − n E bulk 2 A Surface energy of boron adsorbed surfaces γ is calculated as Eq. 3: (3) γ = γ 0 + E ads A As shown in Table S1, the surface energies of unmodified surfaces in this work are consistent with former studies. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Adsorption of boron atoms on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces Previous studies suggest that boron exists in catalysts either in the form of boride or boron oxide [32,33]. Among the possible models for the interactions between boron and catalyst surface, surface adsorption is the simplest and is a suitable starting point of exploration. Adsorption of boron atom on various χ-Fe5C2 surfaces, including 9 low Miller index facets (001), (010)0.25, (011), (101), (10 1 ̅ ), (110), (111), (111)0.61 and (11 1 ̅ ), and 6 high miller index facets (510), (021), (311), (31 1 ̅ ), (312) and (31 2 ̅ ) facets have been systematically investigated. Boron adsorbed on all possible sites on each surface has been calculated to find the most stable configurations. For each surface, the most stable configurations were calculated, and the corresponding adsorption energies are compared in Fig. 1 and the configurations are demonstrated in Fig. S1 and S2. The interactions between χ-Fe5C2 surface and the boron atom vary strongly among different exposed facets. The strongest adsorption occurs on the (31−2) facet with E ads= −0.96 eV, and the weakest adsorption occurs on (010)0.25, with the E ads= 0.0 eV. From strong to weak the adsorption energies on all facets are in the order (31 2 ̅ ) > (10 1 ̅ ) > (021) > (101) > (311) > (001) > (31 1 ̅ ) > (510) > (110) > (312) > (111) > (11 1 ̅ ) > (011) > (010)0.25. A careful inspection of all adsorption configurations indicates that there are roughly three possible adsorption modes: On (510), (021), (311), (312) and (010)0.25 surfaces, the boron atom is adsorbed on 4-fold iron site; on (001), (011), (111), (11 1 ̅ ), (110), (101)and (10 1 ̅ ) surfaces, boron bonds to three or four iron atoms and one carbon atoms; and on(31 1 ̅ ) and (31 2 ̅ ) surfaces, boron bonds to three or one iron atoms and two carbon atoms. We also calculated the adsorption of boron atom on (111)0.61 surface, which is a nonstoichiometric carbon-rich surface and is believed to be predominant under FTS stable configure of boron adsorbed on (111)0.61, boron bonds to one carbon and two iron atoms, and the adsorption energy is − 0.02 eV, suggesting adsorption of boron on carbon-rich surfaces are thermodynamically unfavorable. The barriers of B-C bond formation on (111) and (11 1 ̅ ) have been calculated to be 0.19 and 0.10 eV as shown in Fig. S3. Configurations with B-C bond can be easily formed from less stable structures. In the most stable adsorption configurations, B-Fe bond is in the range of 1.9–2.2 Å and B-C bond is in the range of 1.5–1.6 Å, which are close to the bond length of 2.17 Å for B-Fe in Fe2B [52] and 1.56 and 1.68 Å for B-C in boron carbide [53]. To understand the trends observed in the boron and carbon adsorption on different surfaces, we have also calculated the effective charge and the d band center of the surface Fe atom before adsorption, as presented in Table S4. We cannot find a simple linear correlation between the adsorption energy and the d-band center, which indicates that the interactions between the boron atom and χ-Fe5C2 surfaces are complicated and cannot be attributed to some simplistic factors. We further consider boron adsorption at higher coverage. The most stable configurations of two boron atoms on p(1 ×1) supercells and corresponding energies are shown in Figs. S1, S2 and Table S5. On (001), (010)0.25, (111), (111)0.602, (11 1 ̅ ), (312) and (510) facet, boron atoms form dimers with B-B distance of 1.6–1.7 Å, which is close to the B-B bond length in bulk boron. The barrier of boron dimer formation on (510) surface is around 0.1 eV, as demonstrated in Fig. S4. It suggests that the formation of boron dimer is kinetically feasible. The adsorption energies of dimers averaged by the number of boron atoms are more negative than the adsorption energies of a single boron atom on (001), (010)0.25, (111)0.602, and (11 1 ̅ ) surfaces. On (101), (10 1 ̅ ), (110), (021), (311), (31 1 ̅ ), and (31 2 ̅ ), two adsorbed boron atoms are adsorbed at two distinct sites, and the adsorption energies averaged by the boron number are equal to or less negative than that of a single boron atom adsorption. On (011) surface, the averaged adsorption energy of two boron atoms on (011) p(1 ×1) supercell is −0.49 eV, whereas the energy of one atom adsorption is −0.33 eV (Table S4). In Fig. S1c, it can be found that two B-C bond is formed in the 2B-adsorbed configuration. This B-C-B structure is more stable than B-C structure. From Fig. S5 c to f, COHP analysis revealed that bonding interaction between boron atoms and surface is mainly contributed by 2s and 2px orbital of carbon and boron atoms. In Fig. S5 a and b, the energy of 2px is more negative in 2B adsorbed configuration than in 1B adsorbed configuration. In Fig. S5 d-f, it is found that the interaction between B 2 s-C 2 s and B 2px-C 2px exhibit antibonding feature in one boron adsorbed configuration, whereas there are just bonding interactions in two boron adsorbed configuration. It suggests that in the B-C-B structure, the electronic structure of carbon atom is modulated and the interaction between 2s and 2px orbital of carbon and boron atom is enhanced. 3.2 Effect of boron adsorption on crystallite morphology As the adsorption energies of boron atom on different exposed surfaces of χ-Fe5C2 are different, one can expect that the presence of boron promoters will alter the morphology of catalyst particles by modulating the surface energy [54]. To evaluate the influence of the boron adsorption on the crystallite morphology of χ-Fe5C2, Wulff constructions of particles with adsorbed boron from 1/40–1/6 monolayer (ML) are built and presented in Fig. 2. Considering the interactions between adsorbed boron atoms, adsorption energies at supercells of different sizes were calculated and the adsorption energies at specific boron coverage were estimated by interpolation or extrapolation of computed data in Table S6. As the ratio of (011) and (101) surfaces in all the Wulff constructions are very low, the corresponding data were not included. The relative areas of surfaces from the Wulff construction are listed in Table 1. In general, the overall shape of χ-Fe5C2 particle has not been altered to large extent. Whatever the amount of boron loaded, (510) facet is dominant in the particles with the equilibrium shape. Owing to the medium binding strength of boron on (510) surface which is predominant in unmodified χ-Fe5C2 crystal, the area of this facet remains almost constant at different boron coverage. Increasing the amount of adsorbed boron, facets of high Miller indices (021), (311) and (31 2 ̅ ) expand while facets (010), (11 1 ̅ ) shrink. This result is also consistent with the fact that boron atom is adsorbed strongly on the former three facets and quite weak on the last two facets. It is worth noting that the adsorption energy of boron atom on (001) surface is very negative, whereas the surface area just increases from 6.7% to 8.5% when the boron coverage increases from 0 to 1/10 ML. 3.3 Effect of boron atom adsorption on stability and activity Next, the influence of boron adsorption on the stability and activity of χ-Fe5C2 catalyst were evaluated. In Figs. S1 and S2, The most stable configurations of carbon atom adsorbed on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces are presented to compare with boron. On (010)0.25, (011), (110), (111), (111)0.61, (11 1 ̅ ), (021), (510) and (311), boron atoms and carbon atoms are adsorbed at the same sites with the same modes. On (001), (10 1 ̅ ) and (312), boron atom is bonded next to the most stable sites of carbon atoms. It suggests that on most facets of χ-Fe5C2, there is a competition between boron and carbon adsorption. In other words, adsorbed boron atoms will block the sites for carbon deposition and prohibit coke nucleation and growth. To further identify the anti-coking effect of boron adsorption, we chose the (510) surface, which is the most exposed facet with or without boron modification according to the Wulff construction, to investigate the influence of co-adsorbed boron on carbon atom adsorption. The most stable configurations of carbon atoms adsorbed on boron-free and boron adsorbed (510) surfaces are shown in Fig. 3a and f. With the presence of the boron atom, the adsorption energy of the carbon atom increases by 0.34 eV, which indicates the repulsive interaction between adsorbed boron and carbon atoms. In terms of the data collected in Table 2, the binding strength of carbon to the surfaces of χ-Fe5C2 is about 0.1–0.8 eV more positive when the distance between boron and carbon atoms falls in the range of 2.4–4.4 Å. Increasing the B-C distance leads to weaker repulsive effect. In general, coking tends to occur on electron-rich surfaces and is suppressed on electron-deficient surfaces [23]. From the charge density difference of boron adsorbed surface in Fig. 4a, it is observed that the electron density of boron-bonded iron atoms is depleted, indicating iron to boron electron transfer. As presented in Fig. 4b, projected crystal orbital Hamilton population (pCOHP) analysis reveals that bonding interactions between adsorbed carbon atom and iron atoms is weakened due to the electron-deficient nature of boron modified surfaces [48]. Thus, boron adsorbed χ-Fe5C2 surfaces are expected to be more coke resistant, as boron atoms block the site of carbon deposition and repel adsorbed carbon atoms. The influence of pre-adsorbed boron atom on the adsorption of O, H and CO on the (510) surface was also investigated. The most stable structures and adsorption energies on clean and boron-modified surfaces are shown in Fig. 3. The adsorbing site and energy of hydrogen atom remain unchanged, suggesting that the adsorbed boron atom does not repel the hydrogen atom. The adsorption energy of O is 0.13 eV more negative, which can be ascribed to the formation of B-O bond that stabilizes O on the surface. When boron is adsorbed in the 4-fold hollow iron site, the most stable CO adsorption site moves from the on-top site to a nearby bridge site with the adsorption energy 0.09 eV more positive. The presence of the boron atom has little effect on the H and CO adsorption, indicating that boron atom adsorption does not change the coverage of adsorbed CO and H to a large extent. In other words, the adsorption of boron atom does not alter the FTS reaction by modifying the ratio of H/CO at the surface. To further evaluate the impact of boron adsorption on the catalytic activity, the crystallite morphology of χ-Fe5C2 and reaction barriers under the affection of boron atoms adsorption should be taken into account. When the facets with lower barriers of key elementary reactions are stabilized and exposed more, the activity will be enhanced [54]. With the equilibrium morphologies from Wulff construction, the impact of the boron adsorption on the activity can be estimated. Given the fact that CO activation is the initial step in complicated reaction pathway of FTS and plays important roles in the reaction [55–59], it is chosen as the probe reaction to investigate the modification effect of boron adsorption. Fig. 5, Table S7 and Fig. S7 shows the energies and configurations involved in CO dissociation on the dominant surface (510), expanded surfaces (021), (311), (31 2 ̅ ) and shrunk surfaces (010)0.25 and (11 1 ̅ ) that are present in the Fe5C2 crystallite. Adsorption energies of CO on these surfaces are in the range of −2.0 to −2.2 eV. The CO direct dissociation barriers on these surfaces differ significantly. On (010)0.25, there is the highest reaction barrier 1.65 eV for CO direct activation. On the (11 1 ̅ ) surface, the breaking of C-O bond is in a carbon assisted manner, in which CO moves to a less stable site with the carbon terminate of CO binding to a lattice carbon atom Cs and then is converted to dissociated O* and CCs* species. As the energy of the initial state is 0.76 eV higher than the most stable configuration, the effective activation barrier is as high as 1.5 eV. On (510), (021), (31 2 ̅ ) and (311) surface, CO dissociation is in a similar mode: CO is first adsorbed on an iron 4-fold site, then the carbon atom stays at the hollow site and oxygen atom moves to an iron 3-fold site or iron bridge site. The barriers on (021), (31 2 ̅ ) and (311) surfaces are all lower than that of the (510) surface by at least 0.2 eV. Among these surfaces, (311) has the lowest barrier of 0.63 eV and the site for CO activation is consistently found to be typical B5 sites on stepped surfaces. According to the computed CO activation barriers, the more exposed surfaces, such as (021), (31 2 ̅ ) and (311) are more heavily affected by boron adsorption and more active, while the less exposed surfaces like (010) and (11 1 ̅ ) are relatively inactive. Above all, as a consequence of boron adsorption, the ratio of exposed highly active surface increase and the overall activity for CO dissociation are enhanced. On the other hand, by comparing the configurations involved in CO activation and that of boron adsorption, the site where boron atom adsorbs most stable are sometimes the reaction sites for CO dissociation. It is necessary to verify whether adsorbed boron atoms block the active site on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces by investigating the barriers of boron atom migration. Here we calculated the activation energies of boron atom diffusion from the most stable sites on (510), (021), (311) and (010)0.25 surfaces with and without the presence of adsorbed hydrogen. As shown in Fig. 6, there are always high barriers for bare boron atom migration on these surfaces except for (010)0.25: the barrier is 1.08, 1.55, 1.88 and 0.36 eV on (510), (021), (311) and (010)0.25 respectively. Generally, migration of boron atom on the surfaces with more negative adsorption energy is kinetically unfavored, whereas migration of weakly adsorbed boron atoms is feasible. However, under the FTS condition, hydrogen atoms on surfaces can make strongly adsorbed boron atoms more mobile. Boron hydrogenation to form BH* is always a slightly endothermic process with small barriers. The activation energy of adsorbed boron hydrogenation is 0.45, 0.28 and 0.27 eV on (510), (021) and (311) surfaces. Then, the barrier of BH* migration relative to most stable adsorbed boron and hydrogen is 0.77 eV on (510), 0.94 eV on (021) and 1.09 eV on (311). Clearly, in the presence of hydrogen, the migration barriers have been reduced by 0.3–0.8 eV and boron atoms can move quite freely on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces and do not block the active sites for CO activation. Moreover, boron atoms can move to surface and subsurface vacant site of carbon under FTS condition. As demonstrated in Fig. S8, boron atom can diffuse to near surface carbon vacancy with a barrier of 1.20 eV in the presence of hydrogen and to subsurface vacancies with a barrier of 0.94 eV on (510) surfaces. As the CO activation on χ-Fe5C2 benefits from boron atom adsorption through morphology modulation, the direct influence of co-adsorbed boron atom on the reaction barrier should be investigated. According to Chen et al., the activation barrier of CO decreases when coordinated iron atoms are less positively charged [59]. It is noted that due to the electron-deficient nature, adsorption of boron atoms makes the charge of surface iron atoms more positive, which not only enhances the coke-resistance, but may also hinder the CO activation. Five surface terminations (510), (021) (311), (010)0.25 and (31 2 ̅ ) were chosen to examine whether there is a promotive or poisonous effect of boron co-adsorption on CO direct dissociation. On each surface, boron atom at 2–4 different sites has been taken into account. The energies and configurations involved in CO dissociation and C-O bond length of CO* on these surfaces are listed Table 3 and Figs. S9 to S13. Besides, two descriptors of CO dissociation on iron carbide surface, the average charge of iron atoms involved in transition state [59] and the sum bond valence (SBVCO) of adsorbed CO are presented. The latter is calculated from the bond length between C and O atoms and surface atoms by empirical equation [57]. According to former studies, less positive charge of iron atoms and high SBVCO lead to lower activation barrier. To compare the adsorption energies of boron, ∆E B-ads defined as ∆ E B − ads = E B − ads − E B − ads − ms are presented in Table 3. E B-ads and E B-ads-ms represent the adsorption energies of boron and adsorption energies of most stable structure. Next to evaluate the impact of adsorbed boron on CO adsorption, ∆∆E stands for the interaction between boron and CO has been calculated as ∆ ∆ E = E init − E init − Bfree − ∆ E B − ads E init and E init_Bfree represent the energies of the initial states of CO dissociation and that on boron free surface. Negative ∆∆E suggests that adsorbed boron stabilizes CO, and vice versa. At the first glance of the results, boron atom has no poisonous effect on CO activation, as most of the barriers just decrease or increase to a small extent. ∆∆E is small in most cases, indicating adsorbed boron neither stabilizes or destabilizes adsorbed CO. As exceptions, there are repulsive interactions between CO and boron in the cases B2 and B3 on (021), and attractive interaction in the cases B1 on (010)0.25. The transition states on B-free surfaces and B pre-adsorbed surfaces are structurally similar. It is assumed that electron would transfer from iron to boron to make the charge of iron atoms more positive, giving rise to higher dissociation barrier. Revealed by the Bader charge analysis, the effect on charge on iron atoms involved in CO dissociation is quite weak. In most cases, the Bader charge of iron atoms remain the same, while in other cases, the maximum variation is less than 0.06. The sum bond valences of adsorbed CO either increase or decrease, but were not in a good correlation with the changes of barriers. Besides, on (051) and (021) surfaces, two addition cases have been considered. Instead of boron atoms, in case BH, co-adsorbed BH can reduced the energies of initial states and do not increase the reaction barrier. When boron atoms are adsorbed in carbon vacancy in case BV, the barriers of CO dissociation are not varied to much extent either. Among the results, the barrier of case B1 on (010)0.25 is reduced to relative larger extent. In this case, CO is adsorbed with carbon termination bond to boron atoms. The C-O bond is activated as the bond length increases from 1.210 Å to 1.333 Å and SBV of CO increases from 6.85 to 8.43. In this case, the energy of boron adsorbed slab without CO adsorption is 0.43 eV higher than the most stable B-adsorbed structure, while the adsorption energy of CO on this surface is close to that on B free surface. The − 0.37 eV ∆∆E indicates the formation of C-B bond can stabilize the system. The activation barrier is 0.5 eV lower and breaking of C-O bond is about 0.6 eV more exothermic. Furthermore, formation of this B-CO configuration form CO adsorbed at another site is kinetically favored with a barrier of 0.33 eV as shown in Fig. S14. This finding implies that the adsorption of boron promotes CO activation through a B assisted pathway. Moreover, the effect of boron atom adsorption on H-assisted CO activation via HCO intermediate has also been investigated on (510), (021), (311) and (010)0.25 surfaces. The energies and configurations involved in H-assisted CO activation have been shown in Table S8 and Figs. S15 to S18. For the reaction barriers, most of the activation energies of hydrogenation and C-O bond scission are closed to that on boron free surfaces, which is similar to the effect on direct dissociation. Compared to direct dissociation, adsorbed boron atoms affect the initial states of H-assisted CO activation to larger extent. Only on (510) surface, boron atoms neither stabilizes or destabilize the initial state, while on (010)0.25, (021) and (311) surfaces, boron atoms at some site destabilize the adsorbed H and CO according to the positive ∆∆E in Table S8. As a result, boron atoms adsorbed at specific site, such as B2 on (021) and B3 on (311), H-assisted activation processes are retarded. It should be noted that among the surfaces studied, H-assisted CO dissociation is only predominated on (010)0.25 surfaces, where the poisonous effect of boron adsorption is not obvious. 4 Conclusion An exploration of the promoter effect of boron atom adsorption on iron-based FTS catalyst has been carried out and demonstrated that boron is a promising promoter that can both enhance the stability and activity of χ-Fe5C2 catalyst. Boron-modified surfaces are more coke-resistance as boron atoms always occupy carbon adsorption site to reduce the probability of coke formation and there is repulsive interaction between adsorbed boron and carbon that weaken binding of carbon to surface. The repulsive interaction can be understood as the presence of boron withdraws electron from coordinated iron atoms and then reduce the strength of Fe-C bond. On boron adsorbed surface, the adsorption energy of hydrogen atom and CO change little while that of oxygen atoms increase due to the formation of O-B bond. It is concluded that boron adsorption has little affection on the surface CO/H ratio. CO activation has been taken as the probe to evaluate the effect of the adsorbed boron atom on catalytic activity and no poisonous but a promotive effect is observed. According to the Wulff constructions, more (021), (311) and (31 2 ̅ ) facets with lower CO activation barrier are exposed when the coverage of boron atoms increases, and make catalyst more active for CO dissociation. Although boron may make the surface iron atoms more positively charged, in most cases the barrier for CO dissociation is not varied to great extent, indicating that the role of adsorbed boron atoms is just spectator. There is also particular situation that boron atom participates in CO dissociation and activates C-O bond. We noted that CO dissociation is not always the rate control step in FTS reaction. Hydrogenation, chain-growth and O removal also play important role in the whole reaction network. We will further investigate the effect of boron modification on other elementary reactions to draw the whole picture. coredata.dc:description: Developing advanced Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) technology to acquire fuel and valuable chemicals from non-petroleum sources more efficiently is one of the important tasks in heterogeneous catalysis and chemical engineering research. With the purpose of improving iron-based FTS catalyst, we explored the modification effect of boron on the χ-Fe5C2 catalyst by density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Boron atom adsorption on χ-Fe5C2 surfaces is considered to modulate the stability as well as the activity of CO activation on FTS process. Anti-coking can be observed when boron atom adsorbs on χ-Fe5C2 catalyst due to the competitive adsorption and repulsive interactions between carbon and boron atoms. More open and active planes, such as (311), (021), and (31 2 ̅ ) facets, can expose in the morphology of χ-Fe5C2 when boron atom adsorbs on χ-Fe5C2. It is found that co-adsorbed boron atoms have little effect on the barrier of CO direct dissociation in most cases, while there is also particular situation that CO is adsorbed and activated on boron with carbon termination. Our work shed light on the promoting effects of boron adsorption on CO activation, which can provide useful guide for the design of novel iron-based FTS catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Boron adsorption and its effect on stability and CO activation of χ-Fe5C2 catalyst: An ab initio DFT study
